div.ab: The parts of a sword are the tang, the tail of the sword, what comes next is the heel, the rest is the blade. The sides are the edge & the point. Some blades, acute in point, have only one side filed in the middle & along the whole length, and are easy to break. The other blades are called of three molds or three grips, which do have a rise in the middle, but it is flat as if it were acute in point but flattened, and s these ones are the safest. The others are are called fluted, which are notched in the middle, & when it is along the whole length, they are just as easy to break as those acute in point & are more troublesome to furbish because the burnishing stick cannot get in. But one makes one in particular which is narrow.

Of the hilt of the sword are the pommel, the branches of the hilt & the cross-guard, which is this iron strip which closes off the branch which is at the end of the heel to stop thrusts from sliding down the hilt. The rings are these two branches in half-round which start from the eye of the guard up to the branch of the cross-guard. The branch that crosses the hilt is called the body. And this escutcheon, by which the sword tail enters and to which all the branches return & are held, is called the eye of the guard.

Then follows the wood of the handle which one glues, or according to the most competent, with gummed wax which is of wax & pitch, because resin would be too hard. They heat it lightly, then rubs the wood of the handle in order that the tang takes hold there, otherwise, if a thread were to come loose, the whole d would break immediately. On iron wire or dog skin, one also puts glue on it. The trimming of which is put on the wood of, which is of silk or thread, is called the cord, which is made from two thr or three threads twisted twined on the spinning wheel, or 4 if the silk is thin. The slightly bigger cord holds better. The rivement, which is also made of silk at both ends of the handle, are called the buttons.

Some handles are made of silk, dogfish skin, reheated iron thread, threads of gold & of fine & false silver & of velvet. Iron thread has a lower price & is the most durable. Next is the handle of silk, if one does not have the convenience of being close to the sea to procure some dogfish skin, which is quite convenient. To The beautiful skin costs fifty or lx sous & 4 or five dozen handles are made from it. This kind gives a good grip even if the hand is sweating. To put it to work, if it is too hard, one soaks it for one or two hours in not quite lukewarm aquafortis, for if it were too hot, it would cook & spoil the skin. It is sewn with black thread.
